unnormalised: Hey everyone, quick update on something I found super interesting while browsing through the news this morning. It seems like the dates are all over the place, especially when it comes to event announcements!
normalised: Like, seriously, yesterday I saw one article saying a conference was scheduled for second february two thousand and twenty five, but then further down, in the body of the article, they mentioned february second, two thousand and twenty five, as if it was a completely different thing. Makes you wonder if they even checked their work! And it’s not just one outlet doing it; saw another post referencing an event happening on the fifteenth august two thousand and twenty four, which is obviously independence day, but imagine the confusion for someone not familiar with the D-D slash M-M slash Y-Y-Y-Y format we use in india.

normalised: And don't even get me started on the times! Trying to coordinate across different time zones is already a headache, but some news sites just make it worse. I read about a press release scheduled for fourteen hundred G-M-T, which, fine, but wouldn't it be helpful to add the corresponding time in I-S-T? Like, seven thirty P-M I-S-T? Just a thought. It’s a minor thing but saves so much time!

normalised: It’s funny, because you'd think in the age of digital calendars and automatic time conversions, this wouldn't be an issue. Give us the full date: twenty sixth july two thousand and twenty four, preferably.

normalised: I wonder what's causing all the inconsistency. Is it a lack of attention to detail? Different style guides? Or maybe just plain laziness? Who knows! Because, at the end of the day, clear communication is key, especially when it comes to something as simple as dates and times.
